results.title: Rice growing in New South Wales
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Dept. of Education
results.brief_description: Introduces briefly the essential soil and rainfall requirements for rice growing in NSW. Shows the steps taken by the farmer to grow the rice, including fertilization, sowing, irrigation and harvesting of the crop.

results.title: Rice Farming [COLOUR]
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description: Classroom film on the Australian rice industry: rice growing in Murrumbidgee irrigation area; preparation of the fields; mechanised sowing in the spring; subsequent flooding of paddy fields until harvesting seven months later; harvesting the crop yielding fifty bags to the acre; complementary crops grown on rice farms during winter; milling processes including sifting, removing full, polishing and bagging at local mills. Half the annual rice crop satisfies the home market; the remainder is exported principally in unpolished form.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday

results.title: Rice and Agricultural Development
results.creator_credit: National Farm Cinema Association of Japan
results.brief_description: Japan, as the most advanced agricultural nation of Asia, has the experience and technique to help Afro-Asian economies, by improvements in agriculture. As part of this assistance, the Ibaraki International Agricultural Training Centre teaches better rice cultivation to foreign students.z

results.title: Rice
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films, Willard Van Dyke and Wheaton Galentine
results.brief_description: Discusses the importance of rice in the life and culture of the people of Asia, pointing out that primitive methods cannot produce enough food for Asia’s rapidly increasing population. Describes the work of two American foundations which have established a research and training centre to assist Asian farmers increase their yield. Written by Howard Enders Narrated by John Connell.

results.title: Ribbon of life: one man's reef
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, Dione Gilmour, David Parer and Elizabeth Parer-Cook
results.brief_description: Alastair Birtles, marine biologist, recounts his journeys of discovery through the mountains of coral of the Great Barrier Reef. Shows how the reef mountains grow, how islands are born, how the reef is a vast living system that is constantly growing, dying and growing again while facing serious threats from man. Brilliant underwater sequences filmed and directed by award winning film-maker David Parer capture the private lives of the creatures inhabiting the coral forests. Densey Clyne contributes on the minute details of the reef’s underwater life.

results.title: Rhythmic Gymnastics
results.brief_description: The sport of Rhythmic Gymnastics has been popular in Europe for many generations and is rapidly becoming increasingly popular throughout the United States. The sport is both fun and challenging for the participants, and its visual beauty appeals to spectators. This video, aimed at gymnastic instructors covers such aspects of the sport as Safety, Warm-up, Basic Movement without Equipment, Basic Movement with Equipment and Skills with Apparatus and demonstrates basic exercises while using the apparatus.

results.title: Rhythmetron: with the Dance Theatre of Harlem and Arthur Mitchell
results.creator_credit: Capital Cities and Milton A. Fruchtman
results.brief_description: Arthur Mitchell, a leading black dancer, talks about the founding of the Dance Theatre of Harlem in 1970. He speaks of his own struggle for recognition in the white world of ballet. The Company dances parts of three ballets: ‘Fete Noire’, ‘Biosfera’ and ‘Rhythmetron’. Choreography by Arthur Mitchell.

results.title: Rhythm of Africa
results.brief_description: Cocteau uses much of the material of his earlier film “L’Amitie Noir”; it records the culture of the Chad people of French Equatorial Africa, showing the arts, the handicrafts, and some of their traditional ceremonial dances which have never before been recorded on film. Rarely heard songs and music, authentically recorded on the spot are another interesting feature of the film.
